li.div: A 19-year-old man presents with generalized aches and pains. He has been treated by his general practitioner for gastritis in the past and by a urologist for a renal calculus. Investigation results are as follows: haemoglobin: 13 g/dL (normal range 13–18 g/dL); white cell count: 4.6 × 10 9 /L (normal range 4.0–11.0 × 10 9 /L); platelets: 250 × 10 9 /L (normal range 150–350 × 10 9 /L); glucose 5.5 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.8 mmol/L); calcium 3.26 mmol/L (normal range 2.1–2.6 mmol/L); sodium 136 mmol/L (normal range 135–145 mmol/L); potassium 4.0 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.1 mmol/L); urea 6.0 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–6.6 mmol/L); creatinine 90 μmol/L (normal range 60–120 μmol/L).

A 31-year-old man presents with muscle weakness, polydipsia and polyuria. His blood pressure is 170/89 mmHg. Haematological investigation reveals the following: haemoglobin: 14 g/L (normal range 13–18 g/dL); white cell count: 6.2 × 10 9 /L (normal range 4.0–11.0 × 10 9 /L); platelets: 302 × 10 9 /L (normal range 150–350 × 10 9 /L); glucose 4.9 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.8 mmol/L); calcium 2.22 mmol/L (normal range 2.1–2.6 mmol/L); sodium 155 mmol/L (normal range 135–145 mmol/L); potassium 2.6 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.1 mmol/L); urea 6.0 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–6.6 mmol/L); creatinine 80 μmol/L (normal range 60–120 μmol/L).

A 20-year-old man presents with muscle weakness. On examination he has buccal mucosa pigmentation. Investigations show: haemoglobin: 13.8 g/dL (normal range 13–18 g/dL); white cell count: 10.2 × 10 9 /L (normal range 4.0–11.0 × 10 9 /L); platelets: 202 × 10 9 /L (normal range 150–350 × 10 9 /L); glucose 2.1 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.8 mmol/L); calcium 2.22 mmol/L (normal range 2.1–2.6 mmol/L); sodium 131 mmol/L (normal range 135–145 mmol/L); potassium 5.2 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.1 mmol/L); urea 4.0 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–6.6 mmol/L); creatinine 90 μmol/L (normal range 60–120 μmol/L).

A 16-year-old man presents with weight gain, polyuria, hirsutism and striae. On examination he has bitemporal hemianopia. Investigations show: haemoglobin: 14.8 g/dL (normal range 13–18 g/dL); white cell count: 8.2 × 10 9 /L (normal range 4.0–11.0 × 10 9 /L); platelets: 302 × 10 9 /L (normal range 150–350 × 10 9 /L); glucose 6.1 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.8 mmol/L); calcium 2.22 mmol/L (normal range 2.1–2.6 mmol/L); sodium 146 mmol/L (normal range 135–145 mmol/L); potassium 2.6 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.1 mmol/L); urea 5.0 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–6.6 mmol/L); creatinine 80 μmol/L (normal range 60–120 μmol/L).

A 34-year-old woman presents with weight gain and constipation. On examination her hands are cold and her pulse is 65 beats/min. Investigations show: haemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL (normal range 11.5–16.5 g/dL); white cell count: 5.0 × 10 9 /L (normal range 4.0–11.0 × 10 9 /L); platelets: 302 × 10 9 /L (normal range 150–350 × 10 9 /L); mean cell volume 105 fl (normal range 78–98 fl); sodium 136 mmol/L (normal range 135–145 mmol/L); potassium 3.6 mmol/L (normal range 3.6–5.1 mmol/L); urea 5.0 mmol/L (normal range 2.5–6.6 mmol/L); creatinine 80 μmol/L (normal range 60–120 μmol/L).

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Conn's disease) is Correct. This patient is hypertensive, with normoglycaemia, hypernatraemia and hypokalaemia. These findings points to excess mineralocorticoid.
